text:
I love reading how others do their content strategy and the approach they take. I recently published a case study explaining how I do mine (<https://www.mintcopywritingstudios.com/blog/fintech-case-study>) and I'd love to read how others do theirs.

Also: what do you think about publishing "how I work" type posts online as a freelancer/agency? Personally I am a fan since it allows me to be fully transparent with clients, but are there any cons?

text:
Hey <@UL2E0QVB3> I just want to give you some advices from my perspective, because I'm in a similar situation and can tell you what I did so far and what my next steps are to increase CR of new newsletter leads:

So, what <@U017WRJTKF1> already said is make an analysis to basically check the status quo of your Blog. We checked via Hotjar, if we actually reach our targeting group and if so, how they behave on our blog.

So next, we understood, that the people on our blog only have the chance to sign up for the NL in our footer. And this I saw in your blog too (except for your main page). Therefore my biggest advice for you is: you need to give more incentives for people to sign up. I checked out a lot of very good blogs and in these best practices you can see, that these blogs do it more more aggressive. Take this example:
• <https://www.intercom.com/blog/>
--> you have 3 times the possibility to sign up.
1. sticky header
2. widget
3. in the bottom 
In this stage I am right now. I'll first transform our blog into a library instead in a chronological way (classical blog style) and in this UX transformation I plan more such incentives for NL sign ups --> on the main site *and* in the articles!

text:
Hey folks! I read the article of <@UJG9WTEKG> about <https://www.animalz.co/blog/library-vs-publication/|blogs being libraries> (:point_right: highly recommend it!) and I loved it. It was a game changer and I convinced my CMO to transform our blog from a "chronological feed of posts"-blog into a library.

Right now I am at this point where I create mockups for developers. For that I'm looking for more best practices. I know the blogs of <https://www.intercom.com/blog/marketing/|Intercom> and <https://lattice.com/library|Lattice> already. :slightly_smiling_face:
• *Do you know more blogs which work like libraries as a good exmple?*
Looking forward to your suggestions :raised_hands:

text:
<@U014PRHQUQ2>  And then there are blogs which are just in chronological order, not categorized into topics nor into pillar pages with various topic clusters. Post 45 - 44 - 43... 
As a reader, I find the library approach more aesthetically pleasing and easy to consume content. I came in for one article, but I'll stay for the whole topic because they cover the topic across the board.
The best article that a reader might have found it useful gets pushed down by recent posts because of the chronological order.

text:
Two questions to ask:
1. If the candidate were a man, would you make him take a test? (I ask, because study after study shows that women are asked to "prove" themselves in job interviews at a significant rate over men. That's not saying men aren't, but that women are asked to prove themselves at a much higher rate.)
2. If the person is a cultural fit, wouldn't that be more important than a track record of the exact skills you need? You can teach skills like writing very easily. If the person is bright and meshes very well with your team, I feel like you already have your answer.

elements.text: Two questions to ask:

If the candidate were a man, would you make him take a test? (I ask, because study after study shows that women are asked to "prove" themselves in job interviews at a significant rate over men. That's not saying men aren't, but that women are asked to prove themselves at a much higher rate.)

If the person is a cultural fit, wouldn't that be more important than a track record of the exact skills you need? You can teach skills like writing very easily. If the person is bright and meshes very well with your team, I feel like you already have your answer.

text: Happy Friday, everyone. I've got a best practices questions: how do you all feel about using a negative in a headline? For instance, saying something like "Don't miss out. Win the home you want . . . ."? Throughout the years I've heard various bits of advice about turning the negative to a positive, but this is the pain my client's users feel so I want to open with it so they recognize the problem we solve right away.

text:
1. yes. Done so with around 10 out of 10 man applicants in the last year.
2. It really depends, if I'm actually not after lots of experience and am prepared to invest in educating the person, I'd go for it. Culture-fit is hard to come by, and if it's important to a company (like it's important for ours), it's not to be casted away easily. Plus, 100% of the world's workforce has been given a chance at some point.

text:
Hi everyone! We’re currently hiring for a <https://campfirelabs.co/head-of-content-and-community|Head of Content> at Campfire Labs. I’d love to hear folks’ thoughts on content marketing hiring best practices:
• If you could give one piece of advice to your past self (before you hired your team) what would it be?
• What recruiting channels were the highest signal to noise ratio? 
• What did you look for in people’s backgrounds? 
• How did you build a diverse candidate pipeline and think about DEI?

elements.text: Hi everyone! We’re currently hiring for a
Head of Content
at Campfire Labs. I’d love to hear folks’ thoughts on content marketing hiring best practices:
If you could give one piece of advice to your past self (before you hired your team) what would it be?
What recruiting channels were the highest signal to noise ratio?
What did you look for in people’s backgrounds?
How did you build a diverse candidate pipeline and think about DEI?

text: A bunch of thoughts on your fourth question (and just my two cents): Hire an outside HR firm to strip names, any references to gender, previous employer names, and educational institutions from resumes to reduce bias in the resume review pool. Advertise in your job posting that you do this, as it will automatically improve the quality of individuals in your application pool. If you're going to use an algorithm to sort through resumes, ensure that it has a proven track record for not being racist or sexist (as almost all of them do, so you'll have to look diligently). Additionally, have an in-house internship programs that 1. pays, 2. is online, and 3. specifically recruits and hires diverse interns to build future full-time hires and leaders of tomorrow. Also, be a place where non-male, non-whites, and non-able-bodied people want to work—have diversity in a significant portion of your leadership positions (50% or higher). Your board should be diverse, too, and hopefully you're striving to have it at least look somewhat similar to the makeup of the country (50 percent non-male, 25 percent with a disability, 1 percent indigenous, 13 percent Black, 18 percent Latinx, 6 percent Asian, not all straight). Beyond the board, if there aren't 5+ non-white males in a 10-person company meeting, you're probably not going to be an attractive company for a diverse candidate to work for.  They might take the job, but if you don't show a continued commitment to improving DEI and listening to your non-white able-bodied male employees, they will leave quickly to find a company that is actually dedicated. You have to walk the walk and talk the talk. I worked for a company once that said it was "focused on DEI" ... lol ... it was focused on saying they were focused on DEI. Don't be that place. (I'm not saying you are, just don't do that. It's icky.)

They might take the job, but if you don't show a continued commitment to improving DEI and listening to your non-white able-bodied male employees, they will leave quickly to find a company that is actually dedicated. You have to walk the walk and talk the talk. I worked for a company once that said it was "focused on DEI" ... lol ... it was focused on saying they were focused on DEI. Don't be that place. text:
It's fallen apart since I left, but the library we built at Eventbrite was a shining example of this. Our marketing content library was even touted to investors in the S-1 when we IPO'd.

One thing about the "libraries vs pub" concept is that the library mindset is the most sustainable approach to content marketing — even if your actual library is ordered chronologically. It frees you from believing your content is disposable and needing to constantly create new things.

Before being laid off because of the pandemic, I was executing a roadmap to build a separate content strategy with a publication mindset. The content produced by this flow of work would have a shorter shelf life but ultimately feed into the evergreen content library, refreshing older content with new data, insight, and real-life examples.

elements.text:

Before being laid off because of the pandemic, I was executing a roadmap to build a separate content strategy with a publication mindset. The content produced by this flow of work would have a shorter shelf life but ultimately feed into the evergreen content library, refreshing older content with new data, insight, and real-life examples.

text:
I had the chance to tune in to this excellent Growth Today podcast on landing page optimization, which got me thinking: what are some b2b SaaS companies who have created websites that set up the problem/solution message clearly? As the content creators - I thought folks in this channel may have some ideas!

Pedro mentions Notion and Basecamp - but I am looking for more! Specifically, I'd love to see a website where they have a page that is "problem/status quo" and a page that is their solution that solves the problem (a single page ideally, but can link to more content from there). <https://growthtoday.fm/pedro-cortes/>

attachments.title: 5 Big Landing Page Mistakes That Are Killing Your Conversions with Pedro Cortés (GMT118) - Growth Marketing Today
attachments.text: Potential customers will visit your website and will have a ton of questions and objections.
attachments.fallback: Growth Marketing Today: 5 Big Landing Page Mistakes That Are Killing Your Conversions with Pedro Cortés (GMT118) - Growth Marketing Today

text: Negative emotions can often be more powerful than positive emotions. It’s still “positive” because you’re implying you’ll provide the solution in the post. I’d say go for it and use the metrics to measure which option works best. :blush:
